bibl.title: Remarks on the acceptance of The Order of Finlay, by Philip Showalter Hench, January 24, 1952

div1.p: This is Hench's speech, made on his acceptance of “The Order of Finlay.” He speaks highly of Finlay and states that one of his most valued possessions is an original copy of Finlay's first paper on yellow fever and mosquitoes.

div1.head: Remarks on the acceptance of The Order of Finlay, by Philip Showalter Hench, January 24, 1952

p.hi: REMARKS ON THE ACCEPTANCE OF “THE ORDER OF FINLAY”

div1.p:
THE FINLAY INSTITUTE, HAVANA, CUBA, JAN 24, 1952
PHILIP S. HENCH, M.D. THE MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA

Dr. Andreu: Among my most valued medical possessions is an original copy (Havana,1881)
of Dr. Finlay's first paper on yellow fever and mosquitos. On more than one occasion
I have read every word of the official translation of that paper.

My familiarity with this work and my love of medical history requires me to say that
the conception of Carlos Finlay was one of the boldest, most original and precise in
the long history of medicine.

So profound and mysterious was the secret of nature which he first tried to uncover
that it took many years before his brilliant theory was proven and accepted. That is
one measure of the difficulties involved.

But now he is honored by the whole world because he was a true servant of all people.
His work and his memory deserve the highest awards of science and the lasting grat-
itude of mankind.

It is a unique pleasure for me to receive this distinction which carries his illus-
trious name, a fraternal honor which I am happy to accept as a representative of the
American medical profession and of the Mayo Clinic.
To you, sir, and to the Cuban people my most sincere thanks.
